findings.title: Commented out code in the codebase
findings.description: Having commented out code increases the cognitive load on an already complex system and hides the important parts of the system that should get proper attention.

findings.title: Users can borrow funds, deposit them, then borrow more
findings.description: A user can borrow funds, deposit them, and then borrow more without any restrictions, potentially leading to unintended consequences.

findings.title: Accounts contains expensive looping
findings.description: The Accounts contract has several functions (getBorrowETH, getBorrowPower, getDepositETH, isAccountLiquidatable, and claim) that contain potentially problematic looping, which can lead to side-effects such as allowing an attacker to intentionally create a massively over-leveraged account or generate FIN tokens at will.

findings.title: Potential side-effects of repeated borrowing and depositing leading to over-leveraged accounts and FIN token mining
findings.description: Repeatedly borrowing and depositing tokens can lead to over-leveraged accounts, allowing attackers to intentionally create a massively over-leveraged account, liquidate it, and exit with a chunk of the system liquidity. Additionally, this behavior enables FIN token mining by artificially depositing and borrowing far more often than normal.
